text: hello this is chef john from food wishes
comm with how to make your own prepared
hot horseradish that's right every time
we do a video that uses horseradish I
always get a bunch of emails from people
claiming that they can't find
horseradish in the jar oh they say they
can find the fresh root but nothing
that's already made so if you're one of
these people that just does not have
access to prepared horseradish or you've
just always wanted to know how to make
you yourself I figured I would show you
how it's done
so let's go ahead and saddle up and
start what is a very simple procedure so
first stop you're going to need some
fresh horseradish root which looks
something like this well actually it
looks exactly like that since that's
horseradish and then before we're able
to process this what we need to do is
peel it so I'm going to take my
heavy-duty potato peeler and peel these
roots right down to the white flesh so
don't worry about peeling too much we
want to be very thorough and like I said
we want to peel everything that's not
white and since I'm pretty sure you're
all clear on the concept of peeling
let's go ahead and move on to what
happens after they're peeled which would
be to take a knife and trim off the ends
and then we're going to cube this up so
I'm gonna go ahead and cut this in half
and then we'll slice it lengthwise and
by the way horseradish is very very
woody and firm so please be very careful
and keep your finger tips out of the way
and then what we'll do is turn it and
just slice it into I don't know quarter
inch half inch pieces and right here I
started slicing I realized I want these
a little smaller so I split them
lengthwise again before continuing on
with the aforementioned slicing and even
though we're actually going to grind
this in a food processor we really do
want to cube them up like this first as
it will process way more easily so we'll
continue on dividing and conquering and
slicing then once we prepare the
horseradish for our prepared horseradish
the rest of this procedure is incredibly
simple what we'll do is process this
horseradish with some nice plain fresh
cold water and then to finish it off all
we're going to have to do is add some
salt and some white vinegar and believe
it or not that is pretty much it so at
this point we can head over to the food
processor and yes you really do need one
of these to make this but if you don't
have one I will give you a couple tips
on the blog it will still make this
possible so we will dump our horseradish
in with a splash of cold water and we
will begin like we always begin with
this stuff will
it's on and off to get it started and
once it gets going we'll give it about a
half minute
at which point we'll stop and scrape it
down just in case any of the bigger
chunks are now mixing in and it's at
this point I must issue a very serious
warning as soon as we take off this top
to stir it up you're going to get hit in
the face with a huge invisible cloud a
fiery horse radish gasps so do not under
any circumstances stick your face in
there and make sure you're working in a
very very very well ventilated room like
I'm talking windows open and fans behind
you blowing the fumes away and I'm not
exaggerating this is like tear gas level
I pain or so I've been told by friends
so we will stir that with the spatula
and continue grinding and we do want to
get this pretty fine and during this
process if you think it needs another
splash of water you are going to go
ahead and add one which is what I'm
doing right here I thought I needed to
be a little wetter so we'll go ahead and
we'll continue grinding adding as much
water as we think it needs until we have
a very very fine mixture that looks
something like this and again let me
reiterate the fumes coming from this
thing are incredibly C really hot in
fact if you own a gas mask that would
not be a bad idea here or maybe just
some ski goggles but anyway that's up to
you you're the mr. Ed Wood to put on
your head and then at this point what
we'll do is wait exactly two minutes
before adding the salt and vinegar and
from what I've heard if you wait a
couple minutes before adding the vinegar
you'll actually increase the heat level
of your prepared horseradish and I'm not
sure the science behind it or if that's
just an old wives tale but I do it
because I remember someone saying that a
long time ago which is why I do a lot of
things so I'm gonna let my mixture sit
there exactly two minutes and once we've
given it a heat generating rest we are
now fine to dump in the salt and our
white distilled vinegar and once we've
added those we're going to continue to
process this until we have a nice very
fine kind of smooth kind of creamy
mixture and just like when we process
our horseradish cubes to begin with it's
going to be up to us to add enough water
to get the proper texture or as I should
say the texture you want so I let that
run for about a minute and I took the
lid off give it the old check with the
spatula again doing my best to avoid
those i searing gases and decide to add
another splash of water
and we'll continue to do that processing
checking adding water if necessary until
eventually we get something that looks
like this and it may sound obvious but
we're we're going for something that has
the consistency of a nice prepared
horseradish from the store so let's go
ahead and take a closer look as I
transfer this into my airtight storage
container and it sure looks like
prepared horseradish and it definitely
definitely smells like prepared
horseradish but does it taste like a
delicious extra hot prepared horseradish
yes yes it does this just has such a
vibrant intense aromatic horseradish
flavor that really is superior to
anything you're going to find at the
market and then once you have transfer
that into some kind of airtight
containers we will seal that up and keep
it refrigerated where it should last for
I don't know at least a month and yes
you can also freeze this but anyway
that's it how to make your own hot
prepared horseradish if you'll excuse me
I'm going to go try to find a nice big
piece of prime rib somewhere so I can
double check that this stuff is as
awesome as I think it is so I really do
hope you try to go out and find some
fresh horseradish root as well as access
to a very well ventilated kitchen and
give this great condiment and pretty fun
project to try soon so head over to food
